text: Working as a director has lots of ups and downs
I guess that is generally the case with all creative jobs
The hardest bit of directing is learning to cope with the element of rejection, again part of any creative job
the director has responsibility for the creative realisation of a film and you meet with resistance all through the process from the people you are working with
I should point out that this is essential and one of the best bits of directing too
this forces you to operate at your best, question all your choices and learn how to have faith in you instincts.

Your state of mind (or my state of mind more accurately!) is a very fluid thing, and the ability to trust my instincts comes and goes over time depending on my general confidence and how a project is going.

It takes a lot of work to get a project of any kind to a position where it has its own momentum. The rejection of ideas is a critical part of that, it should be something that you revel in, but that idea is a counter-intuitive proposition and I find it difficult because I can get frustrated with myself when my first idea isn’t necessarily the best or complete answer to a problem.

Once I get over feeling like that, and get more into the real process of being creative - having lots of ideas and creating a malleable palette of ‘stuff’ to work with - directing becomes instinctive, the collaborations become natural, the trust from you fellow filmmakers starts to come more easily and everyone starts to pull in the same direction. It takes a lot of work to make this happen and its a fragile system, but the rewards of getting over the hurdles of rejection are huge and enjoying the process of being creative with a team of people for me is one of the best things in the world.
there you go, a brief intro to what I enjoy and find difficult about directing.
I’m happy to elaborate on this stuff by looking at some specific examples along the path of making a film
